Comment: China isn't a military dictatorship.  It is a civilian dictatorship. The military doesn't rule.  The party strictly controls the military.  Party state rule is a type of civilian dictatorship.  [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civilian\_dictatorship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civilian_dictatorship)  Military parades are held all over the world including democracies.  They are held even India for the republic day,  Anzac day in Australia,  Bastille parade in France etc. China holds its military parades on Oct 1 for its national day which is the founding of the P.R.C. . Holding military parades for these important days is not really a problem.  Having a military parade for a leader's birthday is the problem.  China doesn't do that.  Actually let alone military parade or celebration in China you can't even discuss or mention about Xi's birthday in the social media. Chinese leaders these days keep their birthdays very anonymous.

Comment: Now you‚Äôre just playing semantic games. Public figure doesn‚Äôt mean ‚Äúpolitician.‚Äù It means someone with a platform and reach, which Trump absolutely had by the late '80s. If you really think grievance and dominance weren‚Äôt central to how he operated back then, you clearly never watched *The Apprentice* or read his hit piece on the Central Park Five. He built his entire brand on public humiliation, control, and the idea that some people just deserve to lose.  I was happy to clarify when the national rebirth framing came into play, because watching the timeline of his trajectory tells us how bad things are going to get. Bury your head in the sand if you want. But analyzing that trajectory is how we fight back.
Author: Kei_the_gamer
